title: The Day of Atonement
shortSummary: Leviticus 16 details the sacred procedures for the Day of Atonement, a solemn annual ritual where the high priest makes atonement for himself, his household, and all Israel. This chapter establishes the priestly duties, the use of sacrificial animals, and the symbolic scapegoat, emphasizing God's holiness and the need for purification from sin. It sets a lasting ordinance pointing forward to the ultimate atonement through Christ.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God's appointed leader who receives and conveys God's instructions to Aaron regarding the Day of Atonement rituals.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who performs the atonement ceremonies, including sacrifices and the sending away of the scapegoat.

keyCharacters.name: Two Goats
keyCharacters.description: Sacrificial animals used in the ritual; one is offered to the LORD as a sin offering, the other is the scapegoat sent into the wilderness symbolizing the removal of Israel's sins.

keyCharacters.name: Fit Man
keyCharacters.description: The person designated to lead the scapegoat into the wilderness, ensuring the removal of sin from the camp.

definitions.definition: The gold lid on the Ark of the Covenant where God's presence appeared; the place sprinkled with blood for atonement.
The live goat upon which the high priest confesses Israel’s sins, symbolically carrying them away into the wilderness.
The act of making amends or reparation for sin, restoring the relationship between God and His people.
Special priestly clothing worn by Aaron during the atonement ritual, symbolizing purity and consecration.

outline.heading: Instructions Following the Death of Aaron’s Sons
outline.description: God instructs Moses to guide Aaron on the proper approach to the holy place, emphasizing the need for holiness and specific offerings to avoid death.

outline.heading: Selection and Use of the Two Goats
outline.description: Aaron casts lots to determine which goat is sacrificed to the LORD and which becomes the scapegoat, symbolizing substitutionary atonement and removal of sin.

outline.heading: The Atonement Ritual Inside the Holy Place
outline.description: Aaron offers sacrifices for himself and the people, sprinkles blood on the mercy seat and altar, and consecrates the sanctuary, highlighting the seriousness of sin and God's holiness.

outline.heading: Confession and Sending Away the Scapegoat
outline.description: Aaron confesses Israel’s sins over the live goat, which is then sent into the wilderness, symbolizing the removal of sin from the community.

outline.heading: Cleansing and Final Offerings
outline.description: Aaron changes garments, washes, and offers burnt offerings; those who handled the scapegoat and sacrifices also cleanse themselves, underscoring ritual purity.

outline.heading: Establishment of the Annual Statute
outline.description: God commands the Israelites to observe the Day of Atonement annually as a solemn rest and affliction of the soul, with the high priest making atonement for all Israel.

application: Approach God with reverence and holiness, recognizing His purity and the seriousness of sin in our lives.
Confess and repent of sin regularly, trusting in Christ’s ultimate atonement that fulfills the Old Testament sacrifices.
Observe spiritual disciplines such as fasting and prayer to humble the soul and seek God’s cleansing.
Recognize the importance of intercession, praying for others as the high priest did for Israel.

keyVerses.text: For on that day shall the priest make an atonement for you, to cleanse you, that ye may be clean from all your sins before the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the purpose of the Day of Atonement: cleansing from sin and restoration before God.

keyVerses.text: And Aaron shall lay both his hands upon the head of the live goat, and confess over him all the iniquities of the children of Israel, and all their transgressions in all their sins, putting them upon the head of the goat, and shall send him away by the hand of a fit man into the wilderness:
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates the symbolic transfer of Israel’s sins onto the scapegoat, emphasizing the removal of sin from the community.

keyVerses.text: And this shall be an everlasting statute unto you, to make an atonement for the children of Israel for all their sins once a year. And he did as the LORD commanded Moses.
keyVerses.significance: This verse establishes the Day of Atonement as a perpetual ordinance, pointing forward to Christ’s once-for-all atonement.
